item.title: UFO conspiracy theories
item.description:
UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia entry delves into the realm of UFO conspiracy theories, primarily focusing on the belief that governments, particularly the United States government, are actively suppressing evidence of extraterrestrial life and technology. It also touches upon theories involving government cooperation with extraterrestrials and the allowance of events like cattle mutilation and alien abduction.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section provides a historical context for UFO conspiracy theories, tracing their origins to pulp science fiction and “lost continent” myths. It mentions Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting and the subsequent surge in UFO reports. Key figures like Donald Keyhoe, who popularized the idea of a government cover-up, and the introduction of the “Men in Black” concept are discussed. The section also highlights the impact of events like the Kennedy assassination and films like Close Encounters of the Third Kind on the prevalence of these theories. It notes the shift in the 1980s towards darker theories involving malevolent aliens and government collaboration, as well as the rise of UFO conspiracy theories in 1990s popular culture. The section concludes with the renewed interest in these theories following Leslie Kean’s reporting on a Pentagon UFO program in 2017.

Mainstream Views ðŸ”—

This section presents the mainstream scientific perspective on UFOs, emphasizing that while unusual sightings have been reported throughout history, there is no solid evidence to support claims of extraterrestrial contact or government cover-ups. It mentions government investigations like Project Blue Book and Project Condign, as well as the role of skeptic organizations like the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry in providing prosaic explanations for UFO sightings. The section also touches upon the psychosocial explanations for UFO beliefs, linking them to folklore, mythology, and new religious movements. It includes Benjamin Radford’s argument against the feasibility of a long-term, global UFO cover-up.

Notable Proponents ðŸ”—

This section identifies key individuals who have promoted UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions Donald Keyhoe, Jacque Vallee, J. Allen Hynek, and Stanton Friedman. It also notes that some proponents, like Richard Shaver and Paul Bennewitz, had mental health issues, while others, like Gray Barker and Bill Moore, confessed to hoaxes or lies. The section lists figures like Barry Goldwater, Lord Hill-Norton, Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, Gordon Cooper, and Edgar Mitchell, who have suggested that UFO evidence is being suppressed. 21st-century proponents such as Paul Hellyer, Garry Nolan, Haim Eshed, Jim Semivan, Harold E. Puthoff, Tom DeLonge, Luis Elizondo, and David Grusch are also mentioned.

In Popular Fiction ðŸ”—

This section explores the presence of government UFO cover-ups in popular culture. It cites films like 2001: A Space Odyssey, Easy Rider, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Total Recall, Independence Day, and Men in Black, as well as TV shows like The X-Files, Dark Skies, and Stargate. It also mentions John Glenn’s appearance on Frasier and the Sidney Sheldon novel The Doomsday Conspiracy.

In Religion ðŸ”—

This section examines the intersection of UFO conspiracy theories and new religious movements. It identifies groups like the Nation of Islam, Scientology, and Heaven’s Gate as proponents of these theories. It also discusses Mormon cosmology and its connection to beliefs about inhabited planets. The section mentions figures like Meade Layne, George Adamski, George Hunt Williamson, and Guy Warren Ballard, as well as UFO religions like Unarius, the Aetherius Society, RaÃ«lism, and the Order of the Solar Temple.

Chronology of UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section provides a detailed timeline of the development of UFO conspiracy theories, starting with Raymond Palmer’s pulp magazine Amazing Stories in the 1940s.

1940s origin in Raymond Palmer’s pulp magazine ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on Raymond Palmer, the editor of Amazing Stories, and his role in popularizing UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions his publication of Richard Shaver’s stories about a secret underground race and Palmer’s claim that governments were aware of spaceships visiting Earth.

Spaceships of “The Shaver Mystery” ðŸ”—

This subsection details Richard Shaver’s claims of telepathic communication with a secret underground race and their mastery of space travel. It notes Shaver’s history of psychiatric problems and the blurring of fact and fiction in his stories.

Kenneth Arnold ignites flying disc craze ðŸ”—

This subsection covers Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting and the subsequent “flying disc craze.” It mentions the Roswell incident and Palmer’s investigation of Fred Crisman’s claims near Maury Island, Washington.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the aftermath of the 1947 flying disc craze, including Palmer’s argument that it proved Shaver’s claims and Shaver’s prediction that the truth about the discs would remain a secret. It also mentions Palmer’s later linking of UFOs to the JFK assassination and Watergate.

National coverage in the 1950s ðŸ”—

This section discusses the increase in governmental and civilian investigative efforts and reports of public disinformation and suppression of evidence.

Aztec “alien bodies” hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection details the Frank Scully’s “alien bodies” conspiracy theory and its subsequent debunking as a hoax perpetrated by confidence artists.

Air Force accounts ðŸ”—

This subsection examines the Air Force’s response to UFO sightings, including General John Samford’s 1952 press conference and the Robertson Panel’s recommendation for public education. It also mentions Al Chop’s role as a press spokesman for Project Bluebook and Ruppelt’s book The Report on Unidentified Flying Objects.

“Philadelphia Experiment” hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the “Philadelphia Experiment” hoax and Morris K. Jessup’s involvement, including the letters he received from “Carlos Miguel Allende” and the annotated copy of his book.

‘Men in Black’ legends ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the origins of the “Men in Black” legend, tracing it back to Gray Barker’s book They Knew Too Much About Flying Saucers.

1960-70s: Growing distrust in government ðŸ”—

This section discusses the increasing government skepticism in the 1960s and 1970s, fueled by events like the Kennedy assassination, the Pentagon Papers, and the Watergate scandal.

Fred Crisman and JFK conspiracy theories ðŸ”—

This subsection examines Jim Garrison’s prosecution of Clay Shaw and the subpoena of Fred Crisman, linking Crisman to the Kennedy assassination and a supposed UFO cover-up.

“Cosmic Watergate” ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the concept of a “Cosmic Watergate,” with J. Allen Hynek’s accusations that Bluebook was a cover-up.

Alien bodies at “Hangar 18” ðŸ”—

This subsection details the legends of alien bodies being stored at “Hangar 18” at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, tracing their origins to science fiction and conspiracy theories.

“Alien Abductions” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the rise of “alien abduction” reports, starting with the Betty and Barney Hill case and the Travis Walton incident. It also mentions Budd Hopkins and Whitley Strieber’s contributions to popularizing these reports.

Close Encounters of the Third Kind ðŸ”—

This subsection examines the impact of the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind on UFO conspiracy theories, noting its dramatization of a government UFO cover-up.

Jesse Marcel and Roswell ðŸ”—

This subsection covers Jesse Marcel’s statements about the Roswell incident and the subsequent rise of Roswell conspiracy theories.

Doty and Lear promote the “Dark Side” ðŸ”—

This section discusses the shift in UFO conspiracy theories towards darker themes in the 1980s, with Richard Doty and John Lear as key figures.

Cattle mutilations and quiet helicopters ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the phenomenon of cattle mutilations and their connection to UFOs, quiet helicopters, and government conspiracies.

Doty deceives mutiliation researchers ðŸ”—

This subsection details Richard Doty’s deception of Paul Bennewitz and Linda Moulton Howe, feeding them false stories of a UFO conspiracy.

Doty and Bill Moore spread bogus MJ-12 docs ðŸ”—

This subsection examines the spread of the Majestic 12 documents by Richard Doty and Bill Moore, and Moore’s subsequent confession that he had intentionally fed fake evidence to UFO researchers.

Lear promotes Bill Cooper and Bob Lazar ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses John Lear’s promotion of Bill Cooper and Bob Lazar, and their respective contributions to UFO conspiracy theories.

Doty spreads “Project Serpo” stories ðŸ”—

This subsection covers Richard Doty’s role in spreading the “Project Serpo” story, a supposed “exchange program” with aliens.

Conspiracies conquer 90s media ðŸ”—

This section explores the proliferation of conspiracy media in the 1990s, including shows like The X-Files and films like Independence Day and Men in Black.

“Alien Autopsy” hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection details the “Alien Autopsy” hoax and its subsequent debunking.

David Icke and reptilians ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses David Icke’s theory that world elites are actually “reptilian” aliens.

Phoenix Lights and Heaven’s Gate ðŸ”—

This subsection examines the Phoenix Lights incident and its connection to the Heaven’s Gate religious group.

21st century ðŸ”—

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_conspiracy_theories

item.title: Alien abduction (disambiguation)
item.description:
Alien Abduction ðŸ”—

This entry serves as a disambiguation page for the term “Alien abduction.” It directs users to various articles related to the concept.

Film ðŸ”—

This section lists films with “Alien Abduction” in their title.

  • Alien Abduction (2005 film): A science-fiction horror film produced by The Asylum.
  • Alien Abduction (2014 film): A science-fiction horror film directed by Matty Beckerman.
  • Alien Abduction: Incident in Lake County: A 1998 found-footage film directed by Dean Alioto.
  • *“Alien Abductions” (Bullshit! episode): A 2003 episode of Penn & Teller: Bullshit!

Other uses ðŸ”—

This section lists other uses of the term “Alien Abduction.”

  • Alien Abduction: An alternate name for the roller coaster Gravitron.
  • Alien abduction insurance: An insurance policy issued against alien abduction.
  • Alien abduction entities: Beings alleged to secretly abduct people.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to a related film.

  • UFO Abduction (film): A 1989 found footage/thriller film.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_abduction_(disambiguation)

item.title: Planetary objects proposed in religion, astrology, ufology and pseudoscience
item.description:
Planetary Objects Proposed in Religion, Astrology, Ufology and Pseudoscience ðŸ”—

This article discusses planetary objects proposed outside of mainstream science, specifically within religion, astrology, ufology, and pseudoscience. These objects lack scientific evidence supporting their existence.

Kolob ðŸ”—

Kolob is a star or planet described in the Book of Abraham, a sacred text in the Latter Day Saint movement. It’s also mentioned in a Latter-day Saint hymn. While the Book of Abraham refers to it as a “star,” it’s commonly viewed as a planet by Latter Day Saints. Kolob is described as the heavenly body closest to the throne of God, and Joseph Smith claimed it “signified” the first creation.

Lilith ðŸ”—

Lilith is a fictitious, invisible moon of Earth, proposed in 1918 by astrologer Walter Gorn Old (Sepharial). He claimed it had the same mass as Earth’s Moon. Sepharial associated it with the Lilith of Jewish legend and claimed it was the same second moon that scientist Georg Waltemath claimed to have discovered earlier. Sepharial claimed to have observed it crossing the Sun. The scientific community had already discredited Waltemath’s moon. Modern astrologers use the name Lilith to refer to the position of the Moon’s apogee. Black Moon Lilith is sometimes defined as the second focus of the ellipse described by the Moon’s orbit.

In Modern Astrology ðŸ”—

In contemporary astrology, “Lilith” or “Black Moon Lilith” denotes a point on a horoscope corresponding to the Moon’s apogee. This point, considered the second focus of the Moon’s elliptical orbit (with Earth as the first), completes a zodiac circuit in approximately 8 years and 10 months, tracking apsidal precession.

Planets Proposed by L. Ron Hubbard ðŸ”—

L. Ron Hubbard, the founder of Scientology, proposed a Galactic Confederacy as part of his cosmology. This confederacy consisted of 26 stars and 76 planets, including Earth, then known as “Teegeeack.” Helatrobus is another planet mentioned in Scientology doctrine.

Ummo ðŸ”—

Ummo is a hypothetical planet believed to be located in the Constellation Virgo. It is described in claims of communication between aliens from Ummo and people on Earth. This information was disseminated through detailed documents and letters sent to esoteric groups and UFO enthusiasts. The Ummo affair gained attention in France and Spain in the 1960s. Ummoism refers to groups interested in studying the ideas presented in the Ummo letters. JosÃ© Luis JordÃ¡n PeÃ±a has claimed responsibility for writing the letters, leading many to believe Ummo is a hoax. Jacques VallÃ©e compared the creators of the Ummo documents to the fictional creators of Borges’ “TlÃ¶n, Uqbar, Orbis Tertius.” Mike Dash notes that Ummoism began on February 6, 1966, in Madrid, when JordÃ¡n PeÃ±a claimed to have seen a UFO. Fernando Sesma Manzano, a contactee, became involved after receiving documents purportedly from the Ummites. Jean-Pierre Petit claims to have detected signs of superior intelligence in Ummite writings and that they have inspired his research in cosmology and magnetohydrodynamics. Antonio Ribera mentions 403 Ummo words in a 1978 compilation. Jean Pollion lists over a thousand words.

Planets Proposed by Zecharia Sitchin ðŸ”—

Zecharia Sitchin’s work has gained attention among ufologists, ancient astronaut theorists, and conspiracy theorists. He claimed to have found evidence in Sumerian texts that extraterrestrials from a distant planet in the Solar System visited/created the human race. His theory involves an astronomical interpretation of the Babylonian creation myth, the Enuma Elish, where he replaced the names of gods with hypothetical planets. Academics consider his work pseudoscience and pseudohistory.

Sitchin’s theory proposes the planets Tiamat and Nibiru. Tiamat supposedly existed between Mars and Jupiter. Its orbit was disrupted by the arrival of Nibiru, which caused Tiamat to collide with one of Nibiru’s moons. The debris formed the asteroid belt and Earth. Sitchin claims the Babylonians associated Nibiru with the god Marduk. He hypothesized it as a planet in a highly elliptic orbit around the Sun, with a perihelion passage some 3,600 years ago. He claimed it was the home of the Anunnaki, who visited Earth in search of gold and created humanity by genetically crossing themselves with primates. Websites such as ZetaTalk have claimed that Nibiru or “Planet X” is a brown dwarf soon to pass close to Earth. Sitchin disagreed it is a star. Sitchin also postulated that Pluto began life as Gaga, a satellite of Saturn which, due to perturbation caused by Nibiru’s passing, was flung into orbit beyond Neptune.

Serpo ðŸ”—

Project Serpo is an alleged top-secret exchange program between the United States government and an alien planet called Serpo in the Zeta Reticuli star system. Details of the alleged exchange program have appeared in UFO conspiracy stories. In 1983, a man identifying himself as United States Air Force Sergeant Richard C. Doty contacted investigative journalist Linda Moulton Howe claiming to be able to supply her Air Force records of the exchange for her HBO documentary The ET Factor, only to pull out without providing any evidence to substantiate his story. In 2005, a series of emails were sent to a UFO discussion group run by Victor Martinez claiming that the project was real. Some variations state that Serpo is the nickname of the extrasolar planet. The first mention of ‘Project Serpo’ was in a UFO email list maintained by enthusiast Victor Martinez.

According to the most common version of the story, an alien survived a crash near Roswell in the later 1940s. This alien was detained but treated well by American military forces, contacted its home planet and eventually repatriated. This led to the establishment of a relationship between the American government and the people of its home world, said to be a planet of the binary star system Zeta Reticuli. Zeta Reticuli has a history in ufology, having been claimed as the home system of the Greys. Twelve American military personnel visited the planet between 1965 and 1978 and that all of the party have since died, from “after effects of high radiation levels from the two suns”.

One criticism of Project Serpo stems from the lack of veracity of one of its alleged witnesses, Sergeant Richard Doty. Doty has been involved in other alleged UFO-related activities, and thus is a discredited source. Additionally, there is no physical evidence supporting the project’s existence. According to Tim Swartz of Mysteries Magazine, Doty, who promised evidence to Moulton Howe before backing out, has been involved in circulating several other UFO conspiracy stories. Bill Ryan, a chief proponent of publicizing the Project Serpo claims, announced on 5 March 2007, that he was stepping down from his role as webmaster for the Serpo material.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Serpo

item.title: Travis Walton incident
item.description:
The Travis Walton Incident ðŸ”—

The Travis Walton incident is an alleged alien abduction that occurred on November 5, 1975, involving American forestry worker Travis Walton in the Apacheâ€“Sitgreaves National Forests near Heber, Arizona. The incident is widely considered a hoax.

Background ðŸ”—

This section provides context for the alleged abduction, noting that in the early 1970s, the National Enquirer tabloid offered a substantial prize for proof of extraterrestrial visitors, which may have motivated the hoax.

Travis Walton and the Turkey Springs forestry job ðŸ”—

This section details the circumstances surrounding Travis Walton’s employment and the forestry contract. Key points include:

  • Location: The forestry job was located in Turkey Springs, about 12 miles south of Heber, Arizona. The crew lived in Snowflake, 30 miles away.
  • People: Travis Walton, his brother Duane, and crew chief Michael H. Rogers are central figures.
  • Financial Motive: Rogers’s forestry contract was behind schedule, potentially leading to financial penalties. The section notes that Walton had a prior criminal record.
  • Contract Details: The Turkey Springs job involved thinning 1,277 acres by August 1975, later extended to November 10. Failure to complete the job could result in a $2,500 penalty.

Barney Hill and NBC’s The UFO Incident ðŸ”—

This section highlights the potential influence of the 1975 NBC television movie The UFO Incident, which dramatized the alleged abduction of Barney and Betty Hill. It suggests that the film may have inspired Walton and Rogers to fabricate their own abduction story. Skeptics and psychologists are quoted arguing that the film could have motivated someone to claim an abduction for attention. It also mentions that Travis Walton told his mother not to worry if he were ever abducted by aliens because he would return safe and sound.

Incident ðŸ”—

This section outlines the events of November 5, 1975, when Michael H. Rogers reported Travis Walton missing. The crew claimed they saw a lit object near the roadway, Walton approached it, and was struck by a light. The crew drove away in fear and returned to find Walton and the object gone. The police were notified, and a search was initiated. Deputy Kenneth Coplan noted the calm reaction of Walton’s mother to the news of his disappearance.

Missing person investigation ðŸ”—

This section details the search efforts and initial investigation following Walton’s disappearance. Key points include:

  • Search Party: A search party of nearly 50 people scoured the Turkey Springs area without success.
  • Family’s Reaction: Law enforcement were surprised by the calm reaction of Travis’s mother, who believed he was no longer on Earth.
  • UFO Interest: It was revealed that Travis, Duane, and their mother were interested in UFOs.
  • Polygraph Tests: Rogers and the crew underwent polygraph examinations to determine if they had harmed Walton. Five were deemed truthful, while one was inconclusive.
  • Act of God Clause: Rogers discussed the Forestry contract and the potential for an “Act of God” clause to excuse the delay.

Walton returns ðŸ”—

This section describes Walton’s reappearance and subsequent events. Key points include:

  • Return: Walton called his sister’s home from a payphone in Heber, Arizona, on November 12, shortly after midnight.
  • Deputy Glen Flake: Deputy Flake witnessed Duane Walton transferring fuel from one car to another after having forgotten to purchase gas before local stations closed. Flake did not reveal that they knew Travis had returned home, and Duane did not tell the deputy that Travis had been found.
  • Medical Attention: Duane sought medical attention for Travis, consulting with a hypnotherapist and later two medical doctors who were also amateur UFO investigators.
  • Sheriff Gillespie: Sheriff Gillespie insisted on interviewing Travis, but Duane and Travis demanded that the interview not be recorded.
  • National Enquirer: The National Enquirer provided a suite at the Sheraton Inn in Scottsdale in exchange for exclusive access to Walton and his story.
  • Polygraph Test: Travis skipped a polygraph interview with police, but was later interviewed by Jack McCarthy a free-lance polygraph examiner arranged by a UFO group and the Enquirer. McCarthy concluded that Travis was engaged in a “gross deception”.
  • Television Interview: Walton appeared on Phoenix television, claiming he lost consciousness and awoke in a hospital-like room with short, bald creatures.

Publicity and popular culture ðŸ”—

This section covers the media attention and cultural impact of the Walton incident. Key points include:

  • National Enquirer Prize: The National Enquirer awarded Walton and his co-workers a $5,000 prize for “best UFO case of the year.”
  • Skepticism: Skeptics, including Philip J. Klass, viewed the story as a hoax for financial gain.
  • Book and Film: Walton wrote The Walton Experience in 1978, which was adapted into the 1993 film Fire in the Sky.
  • Media Appearances: Walton has appeared at UFO conventions and on television, including The Moment of Truth and the Joe Rogan Experience podcast.

Rogers-Walton dispute of 2021 ðŸ”—

This section details a public dispute between Mike Rogers and Travis Walton in 2021. Rogers initially recanted his status as a witness to the abduction, claiming it was a hoax, but later reconciled with Walton and retracted his confession.

Modern views ðŸ”—

This section presents contemporary perspectives on the Walton incident.

Waltons as UFO buffs and pranksters ðŸ”—

This section highlights the Walton family’s interest in UFOs and their reputation for pranks. It suggests that the incident may have been planned by Travis Walton and Mike Rogers. Crew member Steve Pierce expressed suspicion that the incident had been a hoax.

National Enquirer misrepresented polygraph results ðŸ”—

This section notes that the National Enquirer publicized the opinion of a private polygraph examiner who reported the witnesses as being truthful, but omitted all mention of Walton’s prior polygraph examiner who concluded Walton was being “grossly deceptive”.

Contrast with alien abduction syndrome ðŸ”—

This section contrasts Walton’s account with typical alien abduction narratives, noting that Walton didn’t report paralysis, recovered memories, or other common elements.

Possible role of fire lookout tower ðŸ”—

This section presents Robert Sheaffer’s hypothesis that Rogers and the Waltons used a nearby fire lookout tower to create the illusion of a UFO. Sheaffer suggests that Travis walked towards the tower, which was brightly lit, and an accomplice illuminated him with a spotlight.

See also ðŸ”—

This section lists related topics, including lists of reported UFO sightings and solved missing person cases.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travis_Walton_UFO_incident

item.title: Belgian UFO wave
item.description:
Belgian UFO Wave ðŸ”—

The Belgian UFO wave was a series of sightings of triangular UFOs in Belgium from November 29, 1989, to April 1990.

The Sightings ðŸ”—

This section details the timeline and specifics of the UFO sightings during the Belgian UFO wave. It began in November 1989, with reports describing a large, flat, triangular object flying at low altitude. The peak of the wave occurred on the night of March 30, 1990. On that night, an unknown object was tracked on radar, prompting the Belgian Air Force to send two F-16s to investigate. While the pilots didn’t visually confirm the object, many people claimed to have witnessed it. The Control Reporting Center (CRC) at Glons received initial reports of unusual lights moving towards Thorembais-Gembloux. Traffic Center Control at Semmerzake tracked an object on radar, leading to the scrambling of two F-16 fighters from Beauvechain Air Base. The F-16s attempted nine interceptions, achieving radar lock briefly on three occasions, but these locks were later determined to be on each other. Members of the Wavre gendarmerie reported seeing four lights in a square formation, making jerky movements before disappearing.

Patrick MarÃ©chal Hoax Photograph ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the famous “Petit-Rechain photo,” which depicted a black triangular object with lights. The photo was widely circulated and examined by various organizations, including NASA, the French National Centre for Scientific Research, and the Belgian Royal Military Academy. For two decades, the UFOlogical organization SociÃ©tÃ© belge d’Ã©tude des phÃ©nomÃ¨nes spatiaux (SOBEPS) claimed the photo was genuine. However, in 2011, photographer Patrick MarÃ©chal confessed that it was a hoax. He explained that he had constructed the UFO from a polystyrene triangle with lightbulbs to prank his workmates. Brian Dunning discussed the photograph in his Skeptoid podcast, highlighting it as emblematic of the quality of evidence during the Belgian UFO wave.

Explanations ðŸ”—

This section explores various explanations proposed for the Belgian UFO wave. In 1992, Marc Hallet criticized SOBEPS, arguing that the wave was a mass delusion fueled by misinformation. Pierre Magain and Marc Remy suggested that the phenomenon would be better studied by human scientists than physicists. Renaud Leclet and co. proposed that some sightings could be explained by helicopters, with the lack of noise attributed to environmental factors. Jean-Michel Abrassart argued that the beginning of the wave aligns with the psychosocial hypothesis. Auguste Meessen defended the unexplained nature of the wave, prompting rebuttals from Roger Paquay and Jean-Michel Abrassart. Brian Dunning discussed the F-16 chase, noting that radar locks were likely on each other due to atmospheric interference (Bragg scattering). He concludes that the sightings were a psychosocial phenomenon, explaining the lack of substantial evidence.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics for further exploration, including UFO sightings in Belgium, a list of UFO-related hoaxes, and black triangle UFOs.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists all the sources cited in the article.

Further reading ðŸ”—

This section lists additional resources for readers interested in learning more about the Belgian UFO wave.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external websites with additional information about the Belgian UFO wave.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belgian_UFO_wave

item.title: Gulf Breeze UFO incident
item.description:
Gulf Breeze UFO Incident ðŸ”—

The Gulf Breeze UFO incident refers to a series of claimed UFO sightings that occurred in Gulf Breeze, Florida, between November 1987 and May 1988. The events gained widespread attention after the Gulf Breeze Sentinel newspaper published photographs purportedly showing a UFO, provided by local contractor Ed Walters.

Events of November 11, 1987 â€“ May 1, 1988 ðŸ”—

Ed Walters claimed to have been immobilized by a blue beam on November 11, 1987, after which he took photos of a UFO hovering near his home. He reported multiple subsequent encounters, taking more photos and even videotaping the object. Walters also claimed to have witnessed the craft landing and aliens exiting, communicating with him telepathically in English and Spanish, and even being lifted off the ground by a blue beam. He reported a total of nineteen sightings or encounters. On one occasion, he claimed the UFO leaked a liquid that continued to boil for weeks.

Investigation ðŸ”—

Walters initially provided his photographs to the Gulf Breeze Sentinel anonymously. He later admitted to being the photographer and submitted to a polygraph test, which indicated he believed his photos were real. Walters also claimed to have experienced missing time on three prior occasions and under hypnosis, stated he had been abducted by aliens.

Several individuals investigated the claims. Ray Stanford initially questioned the weather data related to the photos but later conceded they were likely taken on the reported day. Phillip Klass dismissed the photos as inauthentic. Robert Nathan from NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory suggested the images were double exposures or manipulated. Ed Gray, the mayor of Gulf Breeze, also concluded the photos were fake.

Budd Hopkins believed Walters’ claims were genuine, citing his polygraph test and refusal of a book deal. Bruce Maccabee found a good chance the photos were real. Willy Smith from UNICAT suggested a support under the UFO in the photos indicated it was a model.

Eglin Air Force Base, located near Gulf Breeze, reported no unusual activity or radar blips during the alleged sightings. Gulf Breeze’s police chief, Jerry Brown, attributed the sightings to hysteria and misidentification of activity at the base.

Eyewitness Reports ðŸ”—

Following the publication of Walters’ photos, numerous other residents reported sightings in the Gulf Breeze area. These reports described orange glows, beams of light, and oval or oblong crafts. Fenner McConnell and his wife Shirley claimed to have seen a disc-shaped aircraft with no wings. Brenda Pollak, a Gulf Breeze councilwoman, reported seeing an orange light and witnessed Walters taking photos of a UFO at Shoreline Park. Santa Rosa County Commissioner John Broxson also claimed to have seen unusual lights. Other residents, like Art and Mary Hufford, and Jeff Thompson, reported seeing similar objects. A tollbooth operator, Jerry Thompson, reported seeing thirteen pink-lighted objects.

UFO Research Group Response ðŸ”—

Supporters of Walters, particularly within MUFON, viewed the mass sightings as evidence of the phenomena’s authenticity. MUFON’s director, Walter Andrus, considered the Gulf Breeze incident their “best case ever.” Donald Ware, MUFON’s Florida director, believed the aliens wanted the photos to be seen.

CUFOS, founded by J. Allen Hynek, deemed Walters’ photos fake due to inconsistencies in the craft’s windows and waviness suggesting reflection off water. Friends of Walters reportedly described him as a prankster who had planned “the ultimate prank” and noted parallels between his story and Whitley Streiber’s book Communion.

Model Discovered ðŸ”—

In 1990, a model resembling the UFO in Walters’ photos was found in the attic of his former home. The model was made of foam plates and drafting paper. Craig Myers of the Pensacola News Journal reported the discovery and was able to duplicate Walters’ photos using the model. Walters denied any knowledge of the model, claiming it was planted.

The discovery of the model caused division within the UFO community. Supporters claimed it was planted, while others expressed doubt in Walters’ claims. It was also revealed that Walters had received a $200,000 book advance and was offered $450,000 for miniseries rights. Additionally, he had a prior criminal record for forgery and auto theft, for which he received a pardon from Governor Bob Martinez.

Renewed Interest After 1990 ðŸ”—

UFO sightings continued at the Pensacola Bay Bridge into 1991. In 1993, a friend of the Walters family admitted to witnessing Ed faking the UFO pictures. Mark Curtis also reported that Walter and his wife had divorced in November 1992, splitting $2.5 million in assets believed to have come from the hoax.

MUFON held its first annual UFO symposium in Pensacola in 1990, which continued for the rest of the decade. The publicity attracted tourists and UFO sightseers, boosting the local economy.

In the Media ðŸ”—

The Gulf Breeze UFO case was featured on Unsolved Mysteries and a TV special called “UFO Cover-UP…Live!”. Eyewitness Shirley McConnell discussed her experience on A Current Affair. Unsolved Mysteries, Inside Edition, and A Current Affair filmed more UFO shows in July 1990.

In a 1994 episode of The X-Files, Fox Mulder mentions the Gulf Breeze UFO photos, stating he knew they were fakes.

Gulf Breeze singer Ken Manning won an award for his song “Gulf Breeze UFO” in 1999.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_Breeze_UFO_incident

item.title: Alien Autopsy (2006 film)
item.description:
Alien Autopsy (2006 film) ðŸ”—

A 2006 British comedy film directed by Jonny Campbell and written by William Davies, Alien Autopsy is a fictionalized account of the events surrounding the infamous “alien autopsy” film promoted by Ray Santilli. The film stars Ant & Dec as Santilli and Gary Shoefield.

Plot ðŸ”—

Ray Santilli and Gary Shoefield recount their story to a documentary maker. In 1995, they travel to the United States to find Elvis memorabilia. They encounter Harvey, a former US Army cameraman, who offers them a film from 1947 depicting the autopsy of an alien from the Roswell UFO crash.

After returning to England, Ray and Gary discover the film has degraded. To avoid repercussions from their investor, Laszlo Voros, they decide to recreate the autopsy film. They use a mannequin and meat products to create a replica alien and film it in Gary’s sister’s living room.

They sell the film, earning a large sum of money. Voros demands a larger share of the profits but is killed in a mysterious accident. Ray and Gary travel to Argentina to promote the film, where they are followed by reporter Amber Fuentes. They produce a fake interview with a homeless man posing as Harvey to maintain Harvey’s anonymity.

Ray and Gary attempt to restore the original 1947 footage, but after viewing the results, they decide to bury the film.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film stars Declan Donnelly as Ray Santilli and Anthony McPartlin as Gary Shoefield. Bill Pullman plays Morgan Banner, the documentary maker. GÃ¶tz Otto portrays Laszlo Voros, and Harry Dean Stanton plays Harvey. Other cast members include Morwenna Banks, Omid Djalili, Jimmy Carr, and Jonathan Frakes as himself.

Reception ðŸ”—

The film received mainly positive reviews, earning a 75% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

Releases ðŸ”—

The film was released as a Region 2 DVD by Warner Home Video on July 3, 2006. In America, it was released as a Region 1 DVD by Warner Home Video on September 21, 2010.

Soundtrack ðŸ”—

The film’s soundtrack includes songs by Supergrass, Pete Moore, The Beloved, Stakka Bo, The Monkees, Stereo MC’s, Tom Jones, Nouvelle Vague, Son of Dork, and Babylon Zoo.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Autopsy_(2006_film)
